ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual reality spaces, here.fm, Virbella
none

We met in Altspace, a social platform in Virtual Reality through the Oculus Quest. Sometimes we met on zoom to discuss things that were incompatible with Altspace, but most of the time if it was possible we took advantage of meeting in VR.
guest lectures, live online tutorials, in person live virtual reality meet ups
We met in Virtual Reality through our Oculus headsets a lot. We also met online through here.fm sometimes.
lecture in VR platform (oculus), zoom
Sometimes a zoom virtual seminar, other times meeting in virtual reality, other times guest presentations
We met in Virtual Reality in the game AltSpaceVR where we could study 3D models that were true-to-life in scale, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: VR capabilities and potential, role of VR in technology space, impact of VR/related technology, insights on what it means to be able to create environments, and a lot more
Basic 3D modeling skills, especially with building VR experiences.
how to use alt space, how to model simple things.
I familiarized myself with the process of creating and implementing 3D models into virtual reality. Many students took their own paths in the class with what form of modeling they wanted to pursue.
virtual reality world. virtual reality business, augmented reality world, unity program, vr presentation
Knowledge of the VR landscape, how to create in VR, etc.

I learned how to 3D model using the Oculus Quest and gravity sketch as well as Unity and AltspaceVr worldbuilding. We also discussed the meaning of VR and how it makes us feel and can change how we view the world as another lens. Also, most importantly, we learned to troubleshoot!
Learned 3D Modeling!
The unique properties of creating virtual reality experiences, an introduction to various tools for 3d modelling, and an introduction to various vr platforms

Use of 3D modeling software blender, how to use the game engine Unity, intuitive game and level design skills, process of how a studio incorporates a game idea and brings it to life, how researches are using ScanIP to create 3D models of the human brain, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: professor's approach to teaching, experiencing VR, learning technical aspects accessible to people without background

The fact that this class was taught primarily in a VR space was a novelty, but I overall think Zoom is a much more engaging way to hold seminars. The class was discussion heavy, especially during the first half of the class. While I felt some conversations were important, I wish we had time to work with different modes of 3D modeling earlier in the semester as well, when we did not have access to the VR headsets. I really enjoyed the projects where we had to think about how to combine models to create a whole experience, but I felt this could've improved if we had some modeling abilities beforehand.
all the assignments felt random, lack of guidance/direction overall.

One weakness, which probably couldn't have been avoided, was that the class was not structured that well. On many occasions, we made decisions at the moment and took a while to start actually doing projects in the class. This is contributed to COVID and with many of us being around the world and not in the same place. A strength of the class was how flexible it was to foster your individual creativity, passion, and focus. YOu should definitely take this class if you already have a sense of self-improvement and growth, otherwise, you may not get much out of the class. The rewards of this class are all up to the student.
high strength of VR ideas/concepts. student needs formal background for application.
Overall, great way to experience VR for the first time and discover the possibilities within this medium. Very interesting way to conduct a class and made me appreciate the field of VR more.

I really enjoyed being able to meet in AltSpaceVR, but I wish I had had more assignments in the beginning of the course or like had the assignments spread out more. Perhaps assign the final project at the start and ask us to design one or two components each week or so to keep us on track and testing out the Unity and gravity sketch features earlier on.
Can be improved if we received some technical training in the course
needs to be more organized
The course took a bit of time to land on its feet primarily due to logistical challenges. I the course would benefit from doing more concrete work right away.
Great course; I thoroughly enjoyed the fact that some of our class sessions were held in VR.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the idea of teaching in VR went well, but I found myself wanting to be in Zoom at times. Exploring different spaces as a response to the pandemic was fun, but I thought time could've been better used for more modeling practice.
The next time around, for sure, the structure and fluidity of the class will go much better since this class was like a guinea pig for how it was to run during COVID.
online meetups, vr meetups fully successful, class discussion is engaging, one on one meetings extremely helpful
This class worked very well in the virtual format.
Awesome to have VR headsets
i liked the class dedicated to discussion about how covid impacts us

The VR meetups definitely succeeded. Personally, I didn't mind not being in-person, as I find that when studying long 3D modeling tutorial videos one needs to be secluded; but I'm not sure how it would be for someone who has not had background experience doing this the way I had, or perhaps wasn't comfortable sitting behind a computer screen for long periods. That being said it was perfect for me.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes strongly recommend this class changed my perspective on a lot of things. Also learned a lot more about technical aspects than I expected to in process

If you would like to discuss the implications of VR, in VR, with a bit of modeling on the side, this class is for you. Classes were almost entirely discussion-based for half the semester, and even when we received the VR headsets, classes were still discussion heavy. Thus, if getting your hands dirty with creating is what you're looking for, this is not the class for you.
maybe when classes are in person

If your interested in XR, Unity, Maya, you should definitely take this class. It is an experience! Many professionals also come and talk to you about their industry and how XR could be used or is related to their field.
I would recommend anyone interested in VR + AR +Architecture application who wants to learn Unity and learn aspects of the current field.
Yes, it's a great chance to try VR and think about how to create with it!

This is an exceptional course for a student who wants a more laid-back class but is interested in dipping their feet into the world of VR. It is a great starting point as a course, but it does not provide all the tools necessary to be building massive interactive worlds with no prior experience. The class can inspire you to continue learning about VR though, and you can learn the bulk of which you can learn on LinkedIn Learning.
Yes!

I would recommend this course to people interested in virtual reality as a platform, especially as I expect it to go smoother next iteration. I don't know if I would recommend the course to someone who just wants to learn how to make 3d models.

Yes; the course is designed such that anyone who has essentially any background or interest can pursue a project they'd like to. For instance, one group made a 3D virtual environment to showcase the health of coral reefs in the ocean. And someone like myself might be more interested in the video game development side of things.
